doc.title: Cosmetics & Personal Care Products Kao Begins Production of Tertiary Amines Americans for First Time: Japan HPC & Beauty Trends (Week of Aug 29)
doc.source_uri: 2025-08-29/Cosmetics Personal Care Products Kao Begins Production of Tertiary Amines in Americas for First Time Japan HPC Beauty Tr_2025-08-29

passages.text: August 29, 2025 04:35 AM GMT
Kao has completed construction of its first plant in the Americas for producing tertiary amines, key intermediates used in surfactants.

Kao to open chemical plant in Texas, US: On Aug 25, Kao announced that it had completed a new tertiary amine production plant in Texas on Aug 22. Tertiary amines, intermediates in surfactant production, are made from vegetable oil via fatty alcohol. According to Kao, it currently holds a \(35\%\) global market share thanks to its proprietary catalyst technology, which enables highly efficient manufacturing. With the opening of this new facility, Kao will have tertiary amine production bases in Japan, the Philippines, Germany, and the Americas, thus establishing a three- region manufacturing network across Asia, Europe, and the Americas.

Characteristics of tertiary amine- derived surfactants: Surfactants, used in detergents and shampoos, come in many types with different applications. Tertiary amines are intermediates for cationic surfactants, which are known for their adsorption to fibers, antistatic effects and antibacterial properties. As reported by Nikkei on Aug 24, they are widely used in products such as dishwashing detergents, disinfectants, hair conditioners, and rust inhibitors. While alcohol is commonly used in disinfectants, high concentrations increase packaging and transport costs and restrict consumer use, such as on airplanes. Kao explains that its "Biore u Hand Sanitizer" achieves high bactericidal performance using cationic components derived from tertiary amines, rather than relying on high- concentration alcohol.

Advantages of producing high added- value materials in house: Kao's chemical business is roughly split equally between external sales and internal consumption, according to the firm. While its segment profitability may appear lower than that of the Global Consumer Care (GC) business, the chemical division is a key driver of innovation for GC products, and also contributes to reducing the cost of goods through internal sourcing.

Unexpected benefits in the US: The original goal was to reduce logistics costs amid rising US demand, as products were previously shipped by sea from other sites. An unexpected benefit is the likely acceleration in acquiring US- based customers who want to avoid tariffs. Even with increased depreciation costs, the chemical business is expected to continue growing profits without significant slowdowns. Beyond earnings, deepening relationships with local users may also create opportunities to expand other business areas.
MORGAN STANLEY MUFG SECURITIES CO., LTD.

Overweight (O). The stock's total return is expected to exceed the average total return of the analyst's industry (or industry team's) coverage universe, on a risk-adjusted basis, over the next 12- 18 months.

Equal- weight (E). The stock's total return is expected to be in line with the average total return of the analyst's industry (or industry team's) coverage universe, on a risk- adjusted basis, over the next 12- 18 months.

Not- Rated (NR). Currently the analyst does not have adequate conviction about the stock's total return relative to the average total return of the analyst's industry (or industry team's) coverage universe, on a risk- adjusted basis, over the next 12- 18 months.

Underweight (U). The stock's total return is expected to be below the average total return of the analyst's industry (or industry team's) coverage universe, on a risk- adjusted basis, over the next 12- 18 months.
Unless otherwise specified, the time frame for price targets included in Morgan Stanley Research is 12 to 18 months.
Attractive (A). The analyst expects the performance of his or her industry coverage universe over the next 12- 18 months to be attractive vs. the relevant broad market benchmark, as indicated below.

In- Line (I). The analyst expects the performance of his or her industry coverage universe over the next 12- 18 months to be in line with the relevant broad market benchmark, as indicated below. Cautious (C). The analyst views the performance of his or her industry coverage universe over the next 12- 18 months with caution vs. the relevant broad market benchmark, as indicated below. Benchmarks for each region are as follows: North America - S&P 500; Latin America - relevant MSCI country index or MSCI Latin America Index; Europe - MSCI Europe; Japan - TOPIX; Asia - relevant MSCI country index or MSCI sub- regional index or MSCI AC Asia Pacific ex Japan Index.

Morgan Stanley Research policy is to update research reports as and when the Research Analyst and Research Management deem appropriate, based on developments with the issuer, the sector, or the market that may have a material impact on the research views or opinions stated therein. In addition, certain Research publications are intended to be updated on a regular periodic basis (weekly/monthly/quarterly/annual) and will ordinarily be updated with that frequency, unless the Research Analyst and Research Management determine that a different publication schedule is appropriate based on current conditions.

Morgan Stanley is not acting as a municipal advisor and the opinions or views contained herein are not intended to be, and do not constitute, advice within the meaning of Section 975 of the Dodd- Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act.

Views contained in a "Tactical Idea" on a particular stock may be contrary to the recommendations or views expressed in research on the same stock. This may be the result of differing time horizons, methodologies, market events, or other factors. For all research available on a particular stock, please contact your sales representative or go to Matrix at http://www.morganstanley.com/matrix.

The value of and income from your investments may vary because of changes in interest rates, foreign exchange rates, default rates, prepayment rates, securities/instruments prices, market indexes, operational or financial conditions of companies or other factors. There may be time limitations on the exercise of options or other rights in securities/instruments transactions. Past performance is not necessarily a guide to future performance. Estimates of future performance are based on assumptions that may not be realized. If provided, and unless otherwise stated, the closing price on the cover page is that of the primary exchange for the subject company's securities/instruments.

The fixed income research analysts, strategists or economists principally responsible for the preparation of Morgan Stanley Research have received compensation based upon various factors, including quality, accuracy and value of research, firm profitability or revenues (which include fixed income trading and capital markets profitability or revenues), client feedback and competitive factors. Fixed Income Research analysts, strategists' or economists' compensation is not linked to investment banking or capital markets transactions performed by Morgan Stanley or the profitability or revenues of particular trading desks.

The "Important Regulatory Disclosures on Subject Companies" section in Morgan Stanley Research lists all companies mentioned where Morgan Stanley owns 1% or more of a class of common equity securities of the companies. derivatives of securities/instruments of companies and may trade them in ways different from those discussed in Morgan Stanley Research.
